thread.title: Delhi AQI still above 300 amid 'very poor' air quality in national capital - The Economic Times
thread.title_full: Delhi AQI still above 300 amid 'very poor' air quality in national capital - The Economic Times

author: ET Online
title: Delhi AQI still above 300 amid 'very poor' air quality in national capital - The Economic Times
text:
Listen to this article in summarized format
Delhi's air pollutionhas not brought any significant relief to the citizens in the last few weeks as air quality continued to remain 'very poor' on Thursday with
Air Quality Index(AQI) above 300 in many areas. As temperatures in North India have experienced a slight dip, the national capital is gripped by a thin layer of
smog.
Tired of too many ads? Remove Ads
As per the
Central Pollution Control Board(CPCB), AQI in Anand Vihar and Delhi Cantonment areas was recorded at 302 with a thin layer of toxic smog.
Aam Aadmi Party(AAP) MP Sanjay Singh on Wednesday expressed concern on Delhi's air pollution and rising AQI. "We have all seen that the AQI in Delhi has crossed 800. No one talks bout finding a permanent solution to this. In Punjab, the incidents of
stubble burninghave reduced. We need to have coordination between Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh and the Central government. The national capital, where the Prime Minister, the President,
MPsand all important people stay, has become the most polluted city in the world..." he said.
After nine days of experiencing "very poor" air quality, the national capital saw a marginal improvement on Tuesday, with the average AQI dropping below 300 and into the "poor" category, which has now returned to the 'very poor' category.
The national capital witnessed strong winds on Wednesday that brought a slight relief, improving the city's AQI to 259 — in the 'poor' category, marking an improvement compared to the pollution spike experienced last week.
Tired of too many ads? Remove Ads
At 4 pm on Wednesday, the 24-hour average AQI stood at 259, compared to 282 on Tuesday, 314 on Monday, and 308 on Sunday, according to data from the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).
According to the pollution control body, an AQI between 0 and 50 is considered "good", 51–100 "satisfactory", 101–200 "moderate", 201–300 "poor”, 301–400 "very poor" and 401–500 "severe".
Mumbai Air Pollution
The financial capital of the country woke up to 119 AQI with a layer of haze and 'moderate' air quality. On Wednesday, Mumbai recorded an AQI of 147, a relief from Tuesday's AQI that stood at 170.
